markdownRemark.html:
What art and profession soever thou hast learned, endeavour to affect it, and comfort thyself in it; and pass the remainder of thy life as one who from his whole heart commits himself and whatsoever belongs unto him, unto the gods: and as for men, carry not thyself either tyrannically or servilely towards any.

XXVII. Consider in my mind, for example’s sake, the times of Vespasian:

prev.excerpt:
Whatsoever is now present, and from day to day hath its existence;
all objects of memories, and the minds and memories themselves…

frontmatter.excerpt: XXIX. Whatsoever is now present, and from day to day hath its existence;
author: Marcus Aurelius

next.excerpt:
There is, who without so much as a coat; and there is, who without
so much as a book, doth put philosophy in practice. I am half naked…
